"**On the Road Again** " is a song recorded by the American [blues-
rock](/wiki/Blues-rock "Blues-rock") group [Canned Heat](/wiki/Canned_Heat
"Canned Heat") in 1967. A driving blues-rock boogie,[2] it was adapted from
earlier blues songs and includes mid-1960s [psychedelic
rock](/wiki/Psychedelic_rock "Psychedelic rock") elements. Unlike most of
Canned Heat's songs from the period, second guitarist and harmonica player
[Alan Wilson](/wiki/Alan_Wilson_\(musician\) "Alan Wilson \(musician\)")
provides the distinctive [falsetto](/wiki/Falsetto "Falsetto") vocal. "On the
Road Again" first appeared on their second album, _[Boogie with Canned
Heat](/wiki/Boogie_with_Canned_Heat "Boogie with Canned Heat")_ , in January
1968; when an edited version was released as a single in April 1968, "On the
Road Again" became Canned Heat's first record chart hit and one of their best-
known songs.

## Earlier
songs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=On_the_Road_Again_\(Canned_Heat_song\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Earlier songs")]

With his record company's encouragement, Chicago blues musician [Floyd
Jones](/wiki/Floyd_Jones "Floyd Jones") recorded a song titled "On the Road
Again" in 1953.[3] It was a remake of his successful 1951 song "Dark Road".[4]
Both songs are based on Mississippi [Delta bluesman](/wiki/Delta_blues "Delta
blues") [Tommy Johnson](/wiki/Tommy_Johnson_\(blues_musician\) "Tommy Johnson
\(blues musician\)")'s 1928 song "Big Road Blues"[5] (Canned Heat took their
name from Johnson's 1928 song "Canned Heat Blues"[6]). Johnson's lyrics
include: "Well I ain't goin' down that big road by myself ... If I don't carry
you gonna carry somebody else". Jones "reshaped Tommy Johnson's verses into an
eerie evocation of the Delta".[7] In "Dark Road" he added:

> Whoaa well my mother died and left me  
>  Ohh when I was quite young, when I was quite young ...  
>  Said Lord have mercy ooo, on my wicked son

And in "On the Road Again" he added

> Whoaa I had to travel, whoaa in the rain and snow in the rain and snow  
>  My baby had quit me ooo (2×)  
>  Have no place to go

Both songs share a "hypnotic one-chord [drone](/wiki/Drone_\(music\) "Drone
\(music\)") piece"-arrangement that one-time Floyd Jones musical partner
[Howlin' Wolf](/wiki/Howlin%27_Wolf "Howlin' Wolf") used for his songs "Crying
at Daybreak" and the related "[Smokestack
Lightning](/wiki/Smokestack_Lightning "Smokestack Lightning")".[7][8]

## Recording and
composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=On_the_Road_Again_\(Canned_Heat_song\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Recording and composition")]

"On the Road Again" was among the first songs Canned Heat recorded as demos in
April 1967 at the RCA Studios in Chicago[9] with original drummer [Frank
Cook](/wiki/Frank_Cook_\(musician\) "Frank Cook \(musician\)"). At over seven
minutes in length, it has the basic elements of the later album version, but
is two minutes longer with more harmonica and guitar soloing.[b]

During the recording for their second album, Canned Heat recorded "On the Road
Again" with new drummer [Adolfo "Fito" de la
Parra](/wiki/Adolfo_%22Fito%22_de_la_Parra "Adolfo "Fito" de la Parra"). The
session took place September 6, 1967, at the Liberty Records studio in Los
Angeles. Alan Wilson used verses from Floyd Jones' "On the Road Again" and
"Dark Road" and added some lines of his own:

> Well I'm so tired of cryin' but I'm out on the road again, I'm on the road
> again (2×)  
>  I ain't got no woman just to call my special friend

For the instrumental accompaniment, Canned Heat uses a "basic E/G/A blues
chord pattern"[10] or "one-chord boogie riff" adapted from [John Lee
Hooker](/wiki/John_Lee_Hooker "John Lee Hooker")'s 1949 hit "[Boogie
Chillen'](/wiki/Boogie_Chillen%27 "Boogie Chillen'")".[11] Expanding on Jones'
hypnotic drone, Wilson used an Eastern string instrument called a
[tambura](/wiki/Tanbur "Tanbur") to give the song a
[psychedelic](/wiki/Psychedelic_music "Psychedelic music") ambience. Although
[Bob Hite](/wiki/Bob_Hite "Bob Hite") was the group's primary vocalist, "On
the Road" features Wilson as the singer, "utilizing his best [Skip
James](/wiki/Skip_James "Skip James")-inspired falsetto vocal".[10][c] Wilson
also provides the harmonica parts.[d]

The basic riff is used again by Canned Heat on "Fried Hockey Boogie", an
eleven-minute boogie by Larry Taylor which showcases the band's musicality
with a series of virtuoso solo performances by members.

## Releases and
charts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=On_the_Road_Again_\(Canned_Heat_song\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Releases and charts")]

"On the Road Again" is included on Canned Heat's second album, _Boogie with
Canned Heat_ , released January 21, 1968, by Liberty Records. After receiving
strong response from airplay on American
"[underground](/wiki/Progressive_rock_\(radio_format\) "Progressive rock
\(radio format\)")" FM radio, Liberty issued the song as a single on April 24,
1968.[13] To make the song more Top-40 AM radio-friendly, Liberty edited it
from the original length of 4:55 to a 3:33 single version. It became Canned
Heat's first single to appear in the record charts.[10][e]

On the singles, Floyd Jones and Alan Wilson are listed as the composers, while
the album credits Jim Oden/James Burke Oden (also known as [St. Louis Jimmy
Oden](/wiki/St._Louis_Jimmy_Oden "St. Louis Jimmy Oden")).[f] "On the Road
Again" appears on several Canned Heat compilation albums, including _[Let's
Work Together: The Best of Canned
Heat](/wiki/Let%27s_Work_Together:_The_Best_of_Canned_Heat "Let's Work
Together: The Best of Canned Heat")_ (1989) and _[Uncanned! The Best of Canned
Heat](/wiki/Uncanned!_The_Best_of_Canned_Heat "Uncanned! The Best of Canned
Heat")_ (1994). Also, it is featured on the soundtrack to [Wim
Wenders](/wiki/Wim_Wenders "Wim Wenders") 1974 film _[Alice in the
Cities](/wiki/Alice_in_the_Cities "Alice in the Cities")_.

##
Influence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=On_the_Road_Again_\(Canned_Heat_song\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Influence")]

Although songs inspired by John Lee Hooker's "Detroit-era boogie"[27] had been
recorded over the years by a variety of blues musicians, Canned Heat's "On the
Road Again" popularized the guitar-boogie or E/G/A riff in the rock world.[8]
As a result, "it's been a standard rock and roll pattern ever since".[8]
Canned Heat used it frequently as the starting point for several of their
extended [jam songs](/wiki/Jam_band "Jam band"), including the 40 minute live
opus "Refried Boogie (Part I & II)" from their late 1968 _[Living the
Blues](/wiki/Living_the_Blues "Living the Blues")_ album. When Hooker recorded
an updated version of "Boogie Chillen'", titled "Boogie Chillen No. 2", with
the group in 1970 for _[Hooker'n Heat](/wiki/Hooker_%27n_Heat "Hooker 'n
Heat")_, it had come full circle.[28]

Several other musicians have recorded "On the Road Again", including [Katie
Melua](/wiki/Katie_Melua "Katie Melua") on her album _[Piece by
Piece](/wiki/Piece_by_Piece_\(Katie_Melua_album\) "Piece by Piece \(Katie
Melua album\)")_ (2005) and Canadian band [Sloan](/wiki/Sloan_\(band\) "Sloan
\(band\)") in a medley with the [Stereolab](/wiki/Stereolab "Stereolab") song
"Transona Five" on _[Recorded Live at a Sloan
Party!](/wiki/Recorded_Live_at_a_Sloan_Party "Recorded Live at a Sloan
Party")_ (1997).
